document_title: Microbiological and Nutritional Analysis of Lettuce Crops Grown on the International Space Station
summary_full: This study investigated the microbiological and nutritional quality of red romaine lettuce grown on the International Space Station (ISS) using the Veggie plant growth system, comparing it to ground-grown controls. Lettuce was grown in three separate experiments (VEG-01A, VEG-01B, VEG-03A) with varying harvest methods. Microbiological analysis included plate counts for bacteria and fungi, and Next Generation Sequencing (NGS) for community characterization. Nutritional analysis focused on elemental composition, total phenolics, anthocyanins, and antioxidant capacity (ORAC). Results showed that while bacterial and fungal counts on ISS-grown lettuce were within expected ranges and no human pathogens were detected, there were some differences in elemental composition (Fe, K, Na, P, S, Zn) and total phenolic levels between flight and ground samples, particularly in the VEG-03A experiment. Anthocyanin and ORAC levels did not differ significantly. The study concludes that lettuce grown in the Veggie system is microbiologically safe for astronaut consumption and provides baseline data for future space agriculture.
key_findings: Lettuce grown on the ISS in the Veggie system was microbiologically safe for consumption, with no detected human pathogens.
Bacterial and fungal counts on ISS-grown lettuce were comparable to or lower than those found on terrestrial produce.
Significant differences were observed in the elemental composition of lettuce grown on ISS compared to ground controls, specifically for Fe, K, Na, P, S, and Zn.
Total phenolic content in lettuce leaves showed differences between space-grown and ground-grown samples, with VEG-03A having lower levels.
Anthocyanin and ORAC levels did not show significant differences between space-grown and ground-grown lettuce.
Microbial community analysis revealed variations in dominant genera between leaf and root tissues, with higher diversity in roots, and some differences noted in the VEG-03A experiment's leaf tissue.
future_research_fields: Investigating the long-term effects of spaceflight on plant nutritional content and phytochemicals.
Optimizing irrigation and environmental controls in space-based plant growth systems to minimize microbial variations.
Further characterization of the plant-microbe interactions in the unique space environment.
Developing standardized microbiological safety guidelines for space-grown produce.
Exploring the potential for nitrogen-fixing bacteria in space-grown plant root systems.

conclusions: Lettuce grown in the Veggie system on the ISS is microbiologically safe for astronaut consumption, with microbial loads comparable to terrestrial produce and no detected human pathogens. While nutritional analysis revealed some differences in elemental composition and phenolic content compared to ground controls, these findings provide crucial baseline data for the continued operation and optimization of space-based agriculture for long-duration missions.
impact_statement: This study validates the safety and provides essential nutritional data for growing fresh lettuce on the ISS, supporting the goal of providing astronauts with supplemental food for long-duration space missions.
